topics.name: Rules of the Air
topics.description: Visual flight rules and instrument flight rules

questions.text: Which ICAO Annex covers Personnel Licensing?
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 1 covers Personnel Licensing, including requirements for pilots, air traffic controllers, and aircraft maintenance engineers.

questions.text: What does ICAO Annex 6 primarily address?
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 6 addresses the Operation of Aircraft, covering commercial air transport, general aviation, and helicopter operations.

questions.text: What is the minimum visibility required for VFR flight in Class E airspace below 10,000 feet MSL?
questions.explanation: In Class E airspace below 10,000 feet MSL, VFR requires 3 statute miles visibility, along with cloud clearance of 500 feet below, 1,000 feet above, and 2,000 feet horizontal.

questions.text: When two aircraft are approaching head-on, what action should each pilot take?

options.text: Both alter course to the right
Both alter course to the left

questions.explanation: According to the Rules of the Air, when two aircraft are approaching head-on or approximately so, both shall alter their heading to the right to avoid collision.

questions.text: What is the validity period of a Certificate of Airworthiness for a commercial transport aircraft?

options.text: As specified by the State of Registry

questions.explanation: The validity period of a Certificate of Airworthiness is determined by the State of Registry. It may be unlimited as long as the aircraft remains in an airworthy condition and maintenance requirements are met.

questions.text: In a turbine engine, what is the primary function of the compressor section?

options.text: Mix fuel and air for combustion

questions.explanation: The compressor section increases the pressure of incoming air before it enters the combustion chamber. This compressed air is then mixed with fuel and ignited, producing high-energy exhaust gases.

questions.text: What happens to engine performance as altitude increases?

options.text: Power output decreases due to reduced air density
Power output increases due to cooler temperatures
Power output increases due to reduced drag

questions.explanation: As altitude increases, air density decreases, resulting in less air mass entering the engine. This leads to reduced power output in normally aspirated engines. Turbocharged engines can maintain power to a higher altitude.

questions.text: What is the purpose of winglets on modern aircraft?

options.text: Reduce induced drag by minimizing wingtip vortices
Increase wing area for greater lift

questions.explanation: Winglets reduce induced drag by disrupting the formation of wingtip vortices. This improves fuel efficiency and can increase range, especially beneficial during cruise flight.

questions.text: In a hydraulic system, what is the typical operating pressure range?
questions.explanation: Aircraft hydraulic systems typically operate at around 3000 PSI (pounds per square inch), providing sufficient force to operate flight controls, landing gear, and brakes while maintaining a reasonable system weight.

questions.text: What is the standard temperature lapse rate in the troposphere?
questions.explanation: The International Standard Atmosphere (ISA) defines a temperature lapse rate of 2°C (or 1.98°C more precisely) per 1000 feet of altitude gain in the troposphere, up to the tropopause.

questions.text: At what altitude is the standard pressure 29.92 inches of mercury (1013.25 hPa)?
questions.explanation: Standard sea level pressure is defined as 29.92 inches of mercury (or 1013.25 hectopascals/millibars). This is the datum for the standard atmosphere and altimeter settings.

questions.text: What type of cloud is associated with thunderstorm development?
questions.explanation: Cumulonimbus (Cb) clouds are large, towering clouds associated with thunderstorms, heavy rain, lightning, hail, and severe turbulence. They can extend from low levels to above 50,000 feet.

questions.text: What weather phenomenon is characterized by a rotating column of air extending from a cumulonimbus cloud to the ground?
questions.explanation: A tornado is a violently rotating column of air that extends from a thunderstorm (cumulonimbus cloud) to the ground. It is one of nature's most dangerous weather phenomena.

questions.text: What causes radiation fog?

options.text: Ground cooling on clear, calm nights
Warm air moving over cold water

questions.explanation: Radiation fog forms when the ground cools by radiating heat on clear, calm nights. The air near the surface cools to its dew point, causing water vapor to condense into fog. It typically dissipates after sunrise.

questions.text: If the center of gravity (CG) is too far aft, what is the primary concern?

options.text: Difficulty in recovering from a stall

questions.explanation: An aft CG reduces longitudinal (pitch) stability, making the aircraft less stable and more difficult to control. In extreme cases, it may be impossible to recover from unusual attitudes.

questions.text: What is the effect of a forward CG on aircraft performance?

options.text: Increased stall speed and greater stability
Decreased stall speed and reduced stability

questions.explanation: A forward CG increases longitudinal stability but also increases stall speed because more tail-down force is required to maintain level flight, effectively increasing wing loading.

questions.text: What is the primary factor that determines the takeoff distance required?
questions.explanation: Takeoff distance is primarily affected by aircraft weight and density altitude (combination of pressure altitude and temperature). Higher weight and higher density altitude both increase takeoff distance significantly.

questions.text: What is the best angle of climb speed (Vx) designed to achieve?

options.text: Maximum altitude gain per horizontal distance
Maximum altitude gain per unit time

questions.explanation: Vx (best angle of climb speed) provides the maximum altitude gain for a given horizontal distance traveled. This is useful for clearing obstacles shortly after takeoff.

questions.text: How does high density altitude affect aircraft performance?

options.text: Decreases performance - reduced power, thrust, and lift
Increases performance - improved power and lift
Only affects jet engines, not piston engines

questions.explanation: High density altitude (hot, high, humid conditions) reduces air density, resulting in decreased engine power, propeller thrust, and wing lift. This increases takeoff distance and reduces rate of climb.

questions.text: At what altitude do most people begin to experience symptoms of hypoxia without supplemental oxygen?
questions.explanation: Most people begin experiencing subtle symptoms of hypoxia (reduced oxygen to tissues) at 10,000-12,000 feet. Symptoms include decreased night vision, mild euphoria, and impaired judgment. Regulations require supplemental oxygen above certain altitudes.

questions.text: What is spatial disorientation in aviation?

options.text: Inability to correctly interpret aircraft attitude and position

questions.explanation: Spatial disorientation occurs when a pilot's sensory perception conflicts with actual aircraft attitude, motion, and position. This often happens in IMC when visual references are lost and vestibular illusions occur.

questions.text: What is the 'leans' in aviation medicine?

options.text: A vestibular illusion causing false perception of bank angle
A medical condition affecting blood pressure

questions.explanation: The 'leans' is the most common form of spatial disorientation. It occurs when a pilot corrects a banked attitude that developed slowly and went unnoticed. After leveling the wings, the pilot feels like the aircraft is banked in the opposite direction.

questions.text: Which aircraft has the right-of-way when two aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude?
questions.explanation: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude (except head-on or nearly so), the aircraft that has the other on its right shall give way. This is the 'right-of-way to the right' rule.

questions.text: What is detonation in a piston engine?

options.text: Uncontrolled explosive burning of fuel-air mixture
Ignition of fuel before spark occurs

questions.explanation: Detonation is an uncontrolled, explosive ignition of the fuel-air mixture in the combustion chamber. It occurs after normal ignition and can cause severe engine damage. It is often caused by using fuel with too low an octane rating.

questions.text: What happens to air density as temperature increases at a constant pressure?
questions.explanation: According to the ideal gas law, at constant pressure, as temperature increases, air expands and becomes less dense. This is why hot days result in high density altitude and reduced aircraft performance.
